channel.title: Teamcity on Learn, Converse, Share
channel.description: Recent content in Teamcity on Learn, Converse, Share

item.title: Update - TeamCity
item.description: As you saw from my last TeamCity post, I was a little frustrated about the fact that I had to create an environment variable to use the NAnt runner.  A colleague, Dru Sellers, contacted me and mentioned the Command Line Build Runner.  He understood that I don’t like my build process to be dependent on anything on the server, so I should be able to deploy my source to any server (minus the website being setup in IIS - automating that process is a post for another day).

item.title: JetBrains TeamCity
item.description:
Being sick today has allowed me to catch up on my ASP.NET MVC knowledge and also move the remainder of my CC.NET projects to JetBrains TeamCity.  Being sick is no fun though. Cough Cough

After reading Sean’s post on TeamCity, my eyes have been opened.  Don’t get me wrong, I have attachments to CC.NET because it’s free and it works.  Setup is a pain sometimes, but not too bad.  On the flip, TeamCity has been amazing.  I migrated all of my CC.NET projects (8) to TeamCity in under 1 hour (of course, I’m using NAnt with my custom build files, so it was strictly web interface setup, but it worked.)
